ARTICLE.TITLE: Editorial: Trump’s appalling assault on mail voting builds off false claims
ARTICLE.TEXT:
Since day one, President Donald Trump has been taking a bat to democratic norms like they’re mailboxes and he’s on a joyride. Now that’s all but literal.

He has blatantly used government resources for some time to help his re-election bid — as reflected in his 2019 shakedown of Ukraine’s leaders, telling them they would only get $391 million in military aid if they “investigated” Joe Biden and his family, and his Saturday promise to give billions of dollars in benefits to the unemployed and tax cuts to the employed without congressional authorization.

Now Trump’s crusade against mail ballots (which he uses himself) and his repeated (discredited) claims they are vulnerable to “tremendous” fraud are leading him down a path no American president has ever taken. On Thursday, in an interview with Fox Business News, he openly said that in order to reduce the U.S. Postal Service’s ability to efficiently process mailed-in ballots, he would oppose any pandemic relief measure from Congress that included new funding for the service. Democrats “need that money in order to have the post office work so it can take all of these millions and millions of ballots,” he said. “If they don’t get [more funding], that means you can’t have universal mail-in voting because they’re not equipped to have it.”

As is true of so many of Trump’s statements, this is false. Mail voting is neither universal nor uniform. Only eight states will mail all voters ballots this fall, up just two from the 2016 election. And unlike California, 32 states don’t count postmarked ballots that arrive after Election Day. While some concerns about “harvesting” — the collection of absentee ballots by third parties — are legitimate, there is no evidence of significant fraud in mail voting.

Advertisement

Mail voting is popular because it works. In 2018, 31 million Americans voted by mail, about a quarter of all voters. After Trump blamed voting fraud for denying him a 2016 popular vote victory over Hillary Clinton, he set up a commission to research his allegations. It disbanded in 2018 after finding nothing to substantiate Trump’s claims. Furthermore, requiring in-person voting during a pandemic is dangerous. Of course it’s smart to promote voting by mail.

Trump counters with more mail voting, “you’d never have a Republican elected in this country again.” Once again, his claim is baseless. That’s why in Florida and North Carolina, with no acknowledgment of his double-talking, Trump this month has actually encouraged mail or absentee voting. He knows he badly needs both swing states to get re-elected. Trump’s personal preference for voting by mail only further makes the case for his hypocrisy.

But the threat he poses to the fall election goes beyond the Postal Service funding fight. The agency’s new leader— Postmaster General Louis DeJoy, a wealthy Trump donor with no Postal Service experience — has imposed several management changes in recent weeks that have slowed delivery of mail, ostensibly on the grounds of the need for efficiency.

The Postal Service has problems, but Trump’s shameful sabotage is only making matters worse.

og.description: No, absentee voting is not riddled with fraud, and, no, mail-only elections are not close to universal
